## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 875, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 475, 92]]<|/det|>
For \(n\) values of the variable \(x\), it is given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 100, 638, 119]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma (x - 50) = 144\quad \mathrm{and}\quad \Sigma x = 944.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 277, 144]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 126, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|> A total of 500 students were asked which one of four colleges they attended and whether they preferred soccer or hockey. The numbers of students in each category are shown in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 116, 697, 250]]<|/det|>
SoccerHockeyTotal
Amos543286
Benn8472156
Canton225678
Devar12060180
Total280220500
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 265, 146, 284]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 265, 895, 284]]<|/det|> Find the probability that a randomly chosen student is at Canton college and prefers hockey. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 281, 920, 299]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 421, 148, 440]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 420, 920, 455]]<|/det|> Find the probability that a randomly chosen student is at Devar college given that he prefers soccer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 440, 920, 459]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 611, 146, 628]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 610, 920, 660]]<|/det|> One of the students is chosen at random. Determine whether the events ‘the student prefers hockey’ and ‘the student is at Amos college or Benn college’ are independent, justifying your answer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 643, 920, 661]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|> Two machines, \(A\) and \(B\), produce metal rods of a certain type. The lengths, in metres, of 19 rods produced by machine \(A\) and 19 rods produced by machine \(B\) are shown in the following back-to-back stem-and-leaf diagram. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 128, 722, 262]]<|/det|>
AB
21124
76302224556
87431123026899
55532243346
4310256
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 269, 821, 291]]<|/det|> Key: 7 | 22 | 4 means 0.227 m for machine \(A\) and 0.224 m for machine \(B\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 316, 148, 333]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 314, 628, 333]]<|/det|> Find the median and the interquartile range for machine \(A\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 316, 920, 333]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 352, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 388, 920, 405]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 425, 920, 441]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 920, 476]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 496, 920, 512]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 532, 920, 548]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 567, 920, 583]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 603, 920, 619]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 638, 920, 654]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 673, 920, 689]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 708, 920, 724]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 744, 920, 759]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 778, 920, 794]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 813, 920, 829]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 848, 920, 864]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 883, 920, 899]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 944, 176, 958]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
It is given that for machine \(B\) the median is \(0.232 \text{m}\), the lower quartile is \(0.224 \text{m}\) and the upper quartile is \(0.243 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 148, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 487, 138]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Trees in the Redian forest are classified as tall, medium or short, according to their height. The heights can be modelled by a normal distribution with mean \(40\mathrm{m}\) and standard deviation \(12\mathrm{m}\). Trees with a height of less than \(25\mathrm{m}\) are classified as short.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 146, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 710, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that a randomly chosen tree is classified as short.

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 593, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the height above which trees are classified as tall.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
A fair three-sided spinner has sides numbered 1, 2, 3. A fair five-sided spinner has sides numbered 1, 1, 2, 2, 3. Both spinners are spun once. For each spinner, the number on the side on which it lands is noted. The random variable \(X\) is the larger of the two numbers if they are different, and their common value if they are the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 153, 146, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 151, 361, 170]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{P}(X = 3) = \frac{7}{15}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 428, 186, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 428, 542, 446]]<|/det|>
Draw up the probability distribution table for \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 428, 920, 446]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways in which the 10 letters of the word SUMMERTIME can be arranged so that there is an E at the beginning and an E at the end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 524, 186, 543]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 524, 920, 559]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways in which the 10 letters of the word SUMMERTIME can be arranged so that the Es are not together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 541, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 759, 92]]<|/det|>
On any given day, the probability that Moena messages her friend Pasha is 0.72.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that for a random sample of 12 days Moena messages Pasha on no more than 9 days.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 688, 186, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 688, 920, 723]]<|/det|>
Moena messages Pasha on 1 January. Find the probability that the next day on which she messages Pasha is 5 January.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 704, 920, 723]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Use an approximation to find the probability that in any period of 100 days Moena messages Pasha on fewer than 64 days.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
